column4: No, fragmentation will not neccisarily increase with time with ext3
describe a scenario in which fragmentation decreases
according to shake, run on my downloads directory (about 100 files, average size 200MB), the average file has 1100 fragments.  That seems sufficiently much to start worrying about defraging

random sampling, without filenames: 3217 extents found, perfection would be 3 extents; 1314 extents found, perfection would be 3 extents; 1817 extents found, perfection would be 3 extents; 1083 extents found, perfection would be 3 extents; 1883 extents found, perfection would be 3 extents
I am not sure what "percentage" might be assigned to a 300MB file with 3000 fragments, but if that is less than 1% then I think that measurement is misleading
I did not make the comment about 1% :)
How much free space do you have?
Something is seriously wrong, because you shouldn't be seeing fragmentation like that

as I said... Create large files until the drive is full.  Delete half the files at semi-random.  Create small files until the drive is 75% full.  Repeat on a regular basis for years.  Presto, significantly greater than 1% fragmentation.
i am aware that my usage pattern (filling the drive up before cleaning it out, while continuing to create small and large files) is very fragmentation-inducing
what I *should* do is stop using the same partition for bittorrent and ~, and stop letting the bittorrent partition fill to 99.8% capacity before cleaning it out.
